key_points: Facebook removed over 16,000 groups trading fake reviews after criticism from the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).
In January 2020, Facebook agreed to better identify and remove groups where fraudulent reviews were being traded.
Fake reviews involve purchasing positive reviews to boost sales or negative reviews to harm competitors, coordinated on Facebook and Instagram.
A follow-up investigation by the CMA found that the illegal trade of fake reviews was still occurring on Facebook.
CMA forced a second intervention, expressing disappointment in Facebook's delayed response.
Facebook committed to suspending or banning users involved in trading fake reviews and introduced new technology to automatically flag such groups.
Facebook spokesperson stated they have extensively engaged with the CMA and fraudulent activities are not allowed on their platforms.
The issue of fake reviews is widespread across the internet, impacting various e-commerce sites.
A Which? investigation in October 2018 found Facebook "factories" producing fake reviews for Amazon.
Investigation found that 71% of headphones on Amazon had perfect five-star ratings, often referring to unrelated products and overwhelmingly unverified.
spokespersons: Andrea Coscelli (Chief Executive, Competition and Markets Authority)
